column2: LONDON, Monday, Sept. 11.--The sinking of four more British merchantmen, presumably by enemy submarines, was announced early today.

The city won a partial victory yesterday in its campaign for liberalization of the United States Housing Authority's restrictions on the annual income of tenants in the Red Hook housing development.

LONDON, Sept.10.--The general trend of commodity prices is upward but already many have come, or are due to come, under government control, and it may be regarded that some reasonable level will be maintained.

It has been so long since he played baseball that only the elder bleacherites remember him as the regular right fielder of the Cincinnati Reds who won the lurid world series of 1919 from the bespattered Black Sox.

PARIS, Monday, Sept.11.--The Polish Agency here reported today that Warsaw was under a continuous long-range artillery bombardment, but that German forces had been repulsed in repeated attacks in the suburbs in which street fighting had been bitter.

An exhibition of Turkish textiles opened at the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Saturday and will continue through Oct. 22. The display includes brocaded silks, velvets and embroideries of the Ottoman period chosen out of the permanent collection of the museum.

TORONTO, Sept.10.--Mineral production in Ontario in tha first six months of 1939 showed an increase of more than $7,000,000 from the first half of 1938 and of $1,500,000 over the peak year 1937. The figure for 1939 is $116,671,909, for 1938 $109,627,617 and for 1937 $115,186,526.

LONDON, Sept. 12--The stock markets are gradually settling down to the new conditions and although the appearance is still far from normal there was a more businesslike air in trading today. PARIS, Sept. 12--Advancing by day and consolidating their gains by night while artillery on both sides is very active at all times, the French forces have continued their progress. Today they went forward in the same sector as yesterday--along the twelve-mile line east of the Saar River.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12--Secretary of State Cordell Hull expects to make a statement soon on the attitude of the United States toward the blockades and counterblockades that are developing in the European war.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12--Federal studies of prices of commodities as they reflect the war boom have been extended to non-agricultural products in the Administration's effort to prevent a recurrence of profiteering such as marked the World War, President Roosevelt said at his press conference today.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 12-- Slouched in his chair in a Quarter Sessions court room today, Cesare Valenti, an ex-convict known as "Jumbo" to his intimates, heard himself described as a "retailer in death" deserving of capital punishment for his alleged part in the operations of Philadelphia's arsenic murder ring.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 12--The candidates for Mayor, District Attorney and other offices sponsored by the Republican and Democratic party organizations in a dull campaign were nominated without trouble at today's primary election.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12.--Some retired officers and members of the Fleet Reserve, composed of former enlisted men, would be called to active duty, preferably on a voluntary basis, and the call would go to some members of the Naval Reserve, subject to their consent, Charles Edison, Acting Secretary of the Navy, announced tonight.

The daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 3,228,650 barrels, an increase of 945,450 over the 2,283,200 in the preceding week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. LONDON, Sept. 21--The British people, sitting behind their black and barricaded windows, listened silently over the British Broadcasting Corporation's network tonight to President Roosevelt's neutrality speech and to the loud cheering of Congress every time he mentioned America's determination to stay out of the war.
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings and United States Government securities for the system as a whole to be at the highest of the year to date.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21--The Treasury's Procurement Division, operating under the Strategic and Critical Materials Act, invited bids today for as much as 5,670,000 pounds of Manila fiber (abaca). The bids are to be opened Oct 23.

DETROIT, Sept. 21--Although he asserted last night after his knockout of Bob Pastor that he would not fight again until next Summer, Joe Louis very likely will appear indoors in January.

LONDON, Sept. 21--The stock markets again were able to make a good showing today, although, as was the case yesterday, movements of prices were few and small. WASHINGTON, Sept. 21--During the week ended Sept. 20 member bank reserve balances increased $23,000,000.

YONKERS, N.Y., Sept. 21--Mrs. F.J. Holleran of the Greenwich Country Club won the low gross prize in the women's WestchesterFairfield one-day tournament at the Hudson River Country Club today for her third such award in the last four weekly events of the association. A field of fifty-four competed.

CHICAGO, Sept. 21--With the nation's steel mills moving into high speed to meet the demands of industry generally, the soaring prices of scrap steel and iron are becoming a matter of concern, officials of steel companion said today. Prices of scrap have advanced $4 to $5 a ton here and at Pittsburgh in ninety days.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 21--A controversy over alleged communism in the ranks of the Transport Workers Union of America, a C.I.O. affiliate, broke out on the floor of the second biennial convention of the organization in the Hotel Chelsea here today.

BOSTON, Mass., Sept. 21--The U.S.S. Leary, 1,090-ton first-line destroyer of the Atlantic Squadron, hastily left the Boston Navy Yard on a mysterious mission late this afternoon, after police aid had been enlisted in rounding up members of the crew who were on shore leave.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 21-- Having scheduled a regulation game among his various varsity football teams for Saturday morning, Coach Dick Harlow today made wholesale promotions to his first or "red shirt" squad.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21--Hugh McQuillan, special agent in charge of the Treasury's intelligence unit in Districts 2 and 4, with headquarters in New York and Newark, was named today by Secretary Morgenthau to be coordinator in charge of Treasury enforcement activities in his districts. Supervising Agent Garland Williams of the Bureau of Narcotics will be his assistant in this duty.

BOSTON, Sept. 21--One year ago today a tropical hurricane swept through New England, taking 500 lives and causing damage over an area of 15,000,000 acres, conservatively estimated at $300,000,000. Standing in a soil soaked by nearly ten days of continuous rainfall, 2,250,000,000 board feet of timber were blown down, leaving a salvage and fire hazard problem without precedent.

BERLIN, Sept. 21--With German operations in Poland officially declared completed by the army's Commander in Chief and hostilities there confined to mopping up the activities of four scattered sectors, the main remaining job for the military on the Eastern front appeared today to be the rounding up and counting the prisoners and booty in war materiel.

LONDON, Sept. 21--The British Government had not foreseen the present "stand-by war" but had prepared for immediate and continuous air raids, Sir John Anderson, Minister for Civilian Defense, told newspaper men here today.

CHICAGO, Sept. 21--The wheat market continues to fluctuate in an aimless manner, with small buying or selling orders having a decided effect on prices. Public interest is reported by brokers as unusually small.

With Brokers in government loans lightening their holdings, as well as those of their customers, loans to brokers and dealers in securities took a further drop of $25,000,000 to $405,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, according to the statement of the New York City member banks of the Federal Reserve System released yesterday.
Business in the money market continued along small lines, and chiefly in replacements. Quotations remained unchanged.

Consolidated earnings of the United States Smelting, Refining and Mining Company for the first eight months of this year are estimated at $2,657,306 after Federal income taxes, depreciation, depletion, amortization and other charges, the concern reported yesterday. RAYMONDVILLE, N.Y., Sept. 22--Francis P. Cummings, former consulting vice president and director of the Associated Gas and Electric Company, died here yesterday on the farm where he was born. Since 1930 Mr. Cummings has used the farm as his Summer home. His age was 55.

LONDON, Sept. 22 (AP)--Sir Lavens Mathewson Ewart, 55, died at his home in Bangor, County Down, Ireland, last night. Six weeks ago he succeeded his cousin, Sir Robert Heard Ewart, as baronet. Another cousin, Talbot Ewart, 36 East 36th Street, New York City, succeeds to the title.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., Sept. 23--The Greentree Stable's Third Degree, with a bold move that carried him from fifth position to the top, scored an easy victory in the twenty-first running of the $10,000 added Potomac Handicap, witnessed by a crowd of 18,000 today.

Uncertainty hobbled stock trading yesterday and the New York Stock Exchange witnessed the deadest session since the outbreak of hostilities in Europe. Gains alternated with losses, both ranging from fractions to 2 points, and volume was but 562,460 shares, against 1,084,280 the Saturday before.

Builders expecting a good demand in the current Fall market for dwellings on Long Island have just put the finishing touches on homes in their developments. Inquiries indicate brisk activity in the next few weeks and developers are opening up many model homes for visits by prospective buyers.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23--Two famous Gold Cup Class speed boats were tied on points tonight for the President's Cup and, for the first time since Calvin Coolidge started the tradition of sponsoring this trophy back in 1926, it may leave the United States and go over the border into Canada for at least a year.

Verrando, general manager of the Italian Line in the United States, announced yesterday that the company had re-established its full passenger and cargo services between the ports of the United States, Central and South America and the Mediterranean and Adriatic, it was announced yesterday.

Home seekers with a nominal amount of cash can pay for a $4,000 home at the rate of about $32 a month, as compared to a cost of more than $60 a month in pre-depression days, according to a statement issued yesterday by the Federal Home Loan Bank Board.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25--Indicative of the tremendous upsurge of railroad freight traffic in recent weeks was a statement today by W.C. Kendall, chairman of the car service division of the Association of American Railroads, that "it is doubted if there has ever been the degree of acceleration which has occurred within the east month."

LONDON, Sept. 25 (UP)--Reliable informants said tonight that the mission to Russia of the Turkish Foreign Minister, Shukru Saracoglu, was "so important that it may be considered to have a strong bearing on the ultimate outcome of the war."

With the season two weeks old, the Cleveland Rams and Brooklyn Dodgers are setting the pace in forward passing in the National Football League, according to the official statistics announced yesterday.

Plans were filed yesterday for new apartment structures in Man hattan and Queens. The former is to occupy a plot 125 by 86.10 feet at 321-33 East Seventy-seventh Street and is estimated to cost $200,000.
In its election of Nathan Straus and Everett Uberto Crosby as honorary members this week the American Institute of Architects spanned more than a century of American building.

Despite none too good conditions, the surf casters at Montauk report catches of weakfish and stripers over the week-end.

The Group Theatre unexpectedly revised its schedule yesterday, deciding to defer indefinitely its proposed production of Chekhov's "Three Sisters." Instead, it will open the season with a new play by Robert Ardrey entitled "Tower of Light."

The United States Lines announced yesterday that because of steadily increasing operating costs it was immediately raising its passenger fares to Europe by 33 1-3 per cent. It is not raising its westbound fares, so the new rates will not hit the Americans still waiting to be evacuated from Europe.

Buoyancy in domestic railroad issues and foreign dollar loans and generally lower prices for United States Government obligations characterized trading in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.

PRAGUE, Czecho-Slovakia, Sept. 25--Hundreds of Jews trudged through the streets of Prague to their synagogues today bearing their radios. The Gestapo had ordered all radios in Jewish hands turned in and this afternoon they were picked up by trucks and hauled off to an unrevealed destination.

NANCY , France, Sept. 25--The first front newspaper appeared in this vicinity today in the shape of a one-page sheet with the title, "Le Train Qui Regarde le Boeuf." It is published and edited by a supply train regiment.

Not since that time have Cincinnati citizens cheered any pennant winner or seen any part of a world series on the local lot.

The Owens-Illinois Glass Company has reported to the Securities and Exchange Commission arrangements for cutting the interest and changing other terms of its 3 per cent sinking fund debentures which were sold privately in 1937.

War risk insurance underwriters yesterday faced the problem of making their rates reflect the increased risks they feel are involved in insuring cargo shipments consigned to designated "enemies" of England doing business in neutral countries all over the globe.

The Italian Line's Conte di Savoia, which arrived here on Saturday with 2,156 passengers, sailed at noon yesterday for Genoa and Naples with only z38. One of them was Winthrop Rockefeller, 27-yearold son of John D. Rockefeller Jr. and the only one of the five sons to continue in the oil business.

OYSTER BAY, L.I. Sept. 26-- Nyala, the yacht of F.T. Bedford, today won the second race of the New Fork Yacht Club series for the International twelve-meters. She finished more than a minute and a half over twenty miles before Harold S. Vanderbilt's Vim in one of the weirdest weather days afloat.

SEATTLE, Wash., Sept. 26--That the probable effects of the European war on the economy of the United States will increase business and firm up prices in some industries at the outset, but in the end the results will be unfavorable, is
Former Governor Alfred E. Smith will go on the air on Sunday to speak over a nation-wide hook-up in favor of President Roosevelt's program for American neutrality.

COPENHAGEN, Sept. 26 (AP).-- The situation off the Norwegian coast for the last twenty-four hours or more remained a mystery tonight in the absence of British, French or German confirmation of reports telling of a "naval battle."
The number of visiting buyers registered in the market during the week ended yesterday was somewhat higher than the preceding week and almost double that for
LONDON, Sept. 26--The stock markets today followed the traditional trend on the eve of the budget; the policy being to mark time.
MOSCOW, Sept. 26--The sensational announcement was made this evening that Foreign Minister Joachim von Ribbentrop of Germany was about to pay another visit to Moscow, arriving by plane tomorrow.

Railroad shares came into their own yesterday on the stock market as spirited bidding pushed the carriers to the highest levels since 1937 in a late rally which strengthened the remainder of the list.

Nine mounts for the members of the Chilean Army team, which will compete in the military jumping at the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden Prom Nov. 4 to 11, arrived yesterday from Santiago on the Grace liner Santa Rita.

IT was the gallant captain of the Reds, Billy Myers, who struck the blow that just about clinched the pennant for Cincinnati yesterday Funny thing about Myers; he isn't any great hittar, but he has exploded some timely homers for Mild Will McKechnie's crowd this season.

The Community Service Society (the merger of the Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor and the Charity Organization Society) does not open its campaign until Oct. 17, but it wishes its old friends and new to be making preparations to assist in raising 535,000 extra dollars.

Under-Secretary of State Sumner Welles dealt with three important subjects in his brief address before the Inter-American Neutrality Conference at Panama. First, in general terms, he spoke of "our rights and obligations as neutrals."

Hunters should be heartened by the news of the biggest crop of wild ducks in ten years. According to the organized survey of the Manitoba, Alberta and Saskatchewan breeding grounds by Ducks Unlimited, it is announced that the census just completed reveals an increase of 22 per cent in the duck population of the prairie provinces.

War at sea opened with some intensity. All our ships were going around the world in the ordinary way when they were set upon by lurking U-boats, carefully posted beforehand. In the first week our losses in tonnage were half of the weekly losses in tonnage for 1917, which was the peak year of the U-boat attack in the late war.

The Argentine star Ligaroti, who came so far to race but had traversed the country back and forth without a victory this year, finally smashed his way into the winner's circle yesterday at Belmont Park. It was another score for the Howard family as well as for the singer, Bind Crosby.

Dual job-holding by coaches and other athletic officials in New York City's senior high schools was discussed yesterday by the High School Games Committee of the P.S.A.L. at its first meeting of the new school season at the Hotel Astor.
Dr. Nelson P. Mead, acting president of the City College, warned 800 entering freshmen yesterday to be on their guard against propaganda that might involve the United States in war.
Coach Jimmy Crowley announced yesterday that Leonard Eshmont, junior left halfback, would be held on the sidelines when the Fordham Rams experiment on Waynesburg at the Triborough Stadium Saturday.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Sept. 26--The Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938, known as the Wage and Hour Law, is a valid and constitutional exercise of the power of Congress to regulate commerce. United States District Judge Robert Cooper held here today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26--The Civil Aeronautics Authority tonight ordered Laura Ingalls, aviatrix, to show cause why her license should not be revoked for dropping from an airplane peace pamphlets in the neighborhood of the White House. The incident took place this afternoon.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 26 (AP)--Four boat crews reported seeing submarines along the New Jersey coast today, but none was able to determine whether they were foreien craft.

John D.M. Hamilton, Republican national chairman, will be the principal speaker at the meeting of the Republican County Committee of New York County, to be held tomorrow at the Manhattan Center, 311 West Thirty-fourth Street. Organization of the committee and reelection of Kenneth F. Simpson as Republican county chairman are the purposes of the meeting.
BOSTON, Sept. 26--The decisions which may be made at the PanAmerican Congress at Panama may aid in resolving the difficulties caused by the inability of Germany to obtain raw materials and other

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP)--The navy has decided to shift a "pretty fair-sized" force of vessels to Hawaii, in a move which appears to be linked with the European war and international tension in the Far East.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26--Plans were released today by Secretary Hopkins for providing the country with what he described as "the most comprehensive inventory of its business ever taken."

American costumes shown side by side with their originals from the French couturiers were the features of a fashion show held yesterday in the Green Room of Bloomingdale's, Lexington Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street.

Advancing a slogan of "more Fair for less money during October," Harvey D. Gibson, chairman of the board of directors of the World's Fair, announced yesterday that the admission charge would be reduced to 50 cents daily beginning Sunday.

SIMLA, India, Sept. 26--The Marquess of Linlithgow, the Viceroy, today met Mohandas K. Gandhi in pursuance of his policy of maintaining contacts with Indian political leaders. The meeting was at the invitation of the Viceroy and lasted three and one-half hours. No official indication was given about the

Charles E. Denney, president of the Erie Railroad, is to be elected president of the Northern Pacific Railway tomorrow, according to opinion in informed quarters yesterday. The Northern Pacific's presidency has been vacant since the death of Charles Donnelly recently.

ROME, Sept. 26--Italy is going to go on with her peace campaign, it was indicated today, whatever the British and French Governments say about it. There is a genuine conviction in high official circles that there is a chance that the British and French will give

PARIS, Sept. 26--Gunners and aviators were most active on the Western Front today. In the Saarbruecken and Zweibruecken sectors the French heavy artillery continued to pound the first zone of the Westwall while the German artillery persisted in replying southeast of Zweibruecken.

LONDON, Sept. 26--Replying to criticism of the Ministry of Information, Lord MacMillan, the Minister, said in the House of Lords tonight that the policy of the Ministry was that there should be no propaganda in the United States.
A new drug store is to open in the Fifth Avenue shopping district as the result of a lease of the store and basement in 574 Fifth Avenue

Earnings of the Madison Square Garden Corporation so far in 1939 have been running about the same as a year ago, John Reed Kilpatrick, president, told stockholders at their annual meeting yesterday. As to future dividend policy, he said he helieved the directors would follow the policy of paying out in dividend approximately the amount earned.

The liner Orizaba, operating in a special voyage from Galway and Glasgow under charter to the United States Lines, will arrive today with 352 passengers, including 150 survivors of the Athenia, which was sunk by a submarine on Sept. 3. The Orizaba left Galway on Sept. 21.

OTTAWA, Sept. 26 (Canadian Press)--The proposed new neutrality law for the United States, authoritative sources remarked here today, would give Canada a great advantage over the other belligerents in the purchase of war supplies.

WITH THE GERMAN ARMY ON THE WESTERN FRONT, Sept. 26 (UP)--Germany today has massed an army of well over 1,000,000 men on the Western Front, including crack units shifted from the swift conquest of Poland, to wage what probably will be a purely defensive war.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 26--The fate of two more alleged members of Philadelphia's arsenic murder ring was in the hands of juries tonight.

"See My Lawyer," a comedy by Richard Maibaum and Harry Clork, is to be presented tonight by George Abbott at the Biltmore. Milton Berle, making his debut in a play, heads the cast, which also includes Teddy Hart, Eddie Nugent,

Efforts of producers in several lines of primary goods to prevent speculation from driving prices so high as to threaten consumption met with a moderate degree of success yesterday, but they frankly admitted

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 26 --Invitations were issued today to public officials for a preview Saturday night of Westchester's Pageant of Time, an exhibition comprising fourteen large dioramas depicting the colonial history of this area.
Opening prices for the new raw fur season undoubtedly will follow the bullish ideas of fur buyers dealing with the fur trappers, J.D. Silberman of the Silberman Fur Corporation said yesterday.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 26--Gentleman Jim, fresh from the halfmile tracks, surprised a last field in winning the sixty-third renewal of the $2,000 Lexington stake at the Lexington Grand Circuit meet today.

The advance of $5 a ton posted late on Monday by the Lukens Steel Company for all steel products will not be followed by the larger producers at this time, it was ascertained yesterday, but consideration is being given toward an early posting of prices for the first quar ter of next year by leading interests in order that customers may be informed fully well in advance of the cost of their requirements for 1940.
It is not often that one hears in the first days of a new music season a program of such uncommon distinction as that of the Madrigal Singers at the Town Hall last night.

There is one particularly important point to be noted in connection with the new resolution on foreign policy drafted by Senator Pittman and nine of his Democratic colleagues and submitted to the Foreign Relations Committee as a program of action for the special session.

Irving Bacheller celebrated his eightieth birthday last night at the Hotel Algonquin, aided and abetted by a few score alumni of St. Lawrence University and Rollins College who had invited him to dinner.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 26-- Aa 12,000 film craftsmen received a pay increase of 10 per cent, adding an estimated $2,000,000 or $3,000,000 annually to studio payrolls, motion picture producers and leaders of the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes were setting the stage today to
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept. 26-- Mayor La Guardia of New York told a Rotary Club meeting here today that his formula for getting Federal funds was to have a project prepared in advance.

BERLIN, Sept. 26 (UP).--Chancellor Adolf Hitler is considering returning his Ambassador to Washington as a "peace gesture" toward the United States, it "gas reported in well-informed quarters tonight.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP)--J. Howard Pew, president of the Sun Oil Company of Philadelphia, told the Temporary National Economic Committee today that the oil industry was entirely free of monopoly and there was no need for further Federal "regulation" of its operations.

LONDON, Sept. 26--Great Britain is still mistress of the seas, Winston Churchill, First Lord of the Admiralty, told the House of Commons this afternoon in a speech marked by optimism, though tempered with caution and tinged with sarcasm against an enemy that once before tried and failed to bring Britain to her knees by undersea warfare.

NORFOLK, Conn., Sept. 26-- William O'Connor, president of the Norfolk Savings Bank and a trustee of the Mansfieid State Training School and Hospital, died at his home here today after an illness of two months. His age was 78.

BERLIN, Sept. 26--Col. Gen. Baron Werner von Fritsch, molder of the German military might that crushed Poland and former Commander in Chief of the army, who was killed before Warsaw, received a state funeral in a torrential rainfall

Three leaders of the steel industry made public yesterday sharply contrasting views of possible action by Congress on repeal of the arms embargo, each making clear that he was speaking for himself alone and not for his company nor for the steel industry.
ALBANY, Sept. 26 (AP)--The Fall's first snow whirled across Northern New York today, felling communication wires and impeding motor travel in some sections.

With a dazzling array of 10,000 blooms ranging in size from pompoms the size of a button to giant flowers more than fourteen inches across, the American Dahlia Society opened a two-day exhibition yesterday at the Hotel Park Central, Seventh

New York University's football squad drilled for nearly three hours yesterday at Ohio Field, continuing until after sundown in an effort to perfect coordination in both offensive and defensive formations.

LONDON, Sept. 26--Although this war has not yet reached England from the air, every aspect of our life and daily habits has been changed by its evil spell. At the moment the darkness of night and difficulty of transport are the two most radical causes of trouble. The nightly blackout has almost closed down all social life after dark.

The report of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on Aug. 31, issued yesterday by Wendell L. Willkie, president, shows a consolidated net income of $13,034,923 for the period.

While reporting a gratifying, if small, reduction in the fatalities and injuries due to traffic accidents in New York City during the first eight months of this year, as compared with the like period of last year, Mayor La Guardia pointed out several categories of street mishaps which show increases and deserve renewed precaution on the public's part.
A strict literalist, Herbert L. Bruce, only Negro Tammany district leader in New York, believes partners should share and share alike, even when they have a falling out.

PANAMA, Sept. 28--The United States' promise, voiced by UnderSecretary of State Summer Welles yesterday, to maintain and perhaps expand inter-American shipping facilities, excited the interest of delegates to the conference of Pan-American

PORT WASHINTGON, L.I., Sept. 26--The plight of 2,500 United States citizens stranded in Bordeaux, France, many of them with their money gone or giving out and forced to live in automobiles, was related here this afternoon by one of the forty-nine passengers arriving on the Pan American airplane Yankee Clipper from Lisbon.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 3,681,050 barrels, an increase of 258,700 over the 3,422,350 in the preceding week, according to the American Petroleum Institute.

MOSCOW, Sept. 26--Ominous allegations concerning Estonia, especially in view of the reported pending return to Moscow of that country's Foreign Minister, Karl Selter, were issued over the Soviet radio tonight.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26--Colonel Rogers Birnie, United States Army, retired, who during his active service was one of the best known ordnance experts in the army, died here last night at the home of his son-in-law, Colonel Ernest Graves, in his eighty-ninth year.

An intensive program of education directed to both business and consumers on comparative price abuses in advertising will be started by the National Association of Better Business Bureaus, Karl T. Finn,

A special committee of the New York State Bar Association will study whether the practice of laymen representing claimants before a constantly increasing number of governmental boards and agencies constitutes an invasion of the practice of law, Fred L. Gross of Brooklyn, president of the association, announced yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 26--South California's death toll in one of the most disastrous Autumn seacoast storms in its history may reach more than 100, it was estimated tonight on the basis of reports from beach cities, the Coast Guard, harbor masters, lifeguards and yacht basins.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26--United States exports in august this year increased 9 per cent over both July and august of last year, while general imports for the month gained 4 per cent over July and 6 per cent over August last year, the Department of Commerce announced today.

The Democratic primary election in which former Judge Jonah J. Goldstein was nominated as an independent for election to the General Sessions bench by a majority of about 1,500 over one of his two Democratic-Republican opponents, Chief City Magistrate Jacob Gould Schurman Jr., is to be contested today before Supreme Court Justice Lloyd Church.
The 1939 campaign for funds for the Henry Street Visiting Nurse Service, which made 500,000 home visits last year, opened yesterday with a meeting of campaign workers and leaders in the headquarters

CHICAGO, Sept. 26--The American Legion, through a committee, stated its attitude on neutrality today to be that the United States should stay out of war, that Congress should be left to decide whether the present embargo on arms should be continued or changed and "demanded" that the lawmakers stay in session "during the present grave crisis."

The Grace liner Santa Rosa arrived here yesterday from Caribbean ports with 165 passengers, including twelve Jewish refugees who left Germany five weeks ago to enter the United States as quota immigrants.

Reorganization of the New York City evening elementary schools on a drastically curtailed basis, at a saving of $250,000, was voted yesterday by the Board of Superintendents. Twenty-three of the fortyfour schools in operation last year are scheduled to be reopened.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26--President Roosevelt made it clear today that the United States Government was aware of efforts of foreigners to acquire supplies of vital materials which this country is trying to accumulate against the possibility of emergencies.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 26.-- "Twenty Little Working Girls" was placed on Metro's schedule today as the next starring vehicle for Lana Turner, continuing the studio's youth cycle. The yarn by Val Burton and Bradford Ropes was purchased...

Magistrate Matthew J. Troy of Brooklyn, addressing the weekly luncheon meeting of the Lions Club of Brooklyn at the Hotel Bossert in that borough, declared yesterday that a personal survey of court records for 1938 had shown that the largest group of criminals way 30 to 39 years old.

Buoyancy in secondary railroad issues and selected foreign dollar loans featured more active trading in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Trading in domestic corporation issues, in fact,
A special duplex thirteen-room penthouse apartment in the multi family dwelling at 941 Park Avenue has been leased to Dr. Stuart Craig of the medical board of Doctors Hospital by the Tishman Realty
CHICAGO, Sept. 26.--While wheat futures fluctuated in a range of more than a cent a bushel today, trading was quiet.
Francis J. Gavin, executive vice president of the Great Northern Railway, was elected its president yesterday. He succeeds the late William P. Kenney.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 26--Little Billy Myers's big bat kept the leagueleading Reds three and one-half games in front today, his home run with two aboard defeating the Cardinals, 3 to 1, in the first game of their crucial double-header and making it relatively unimportant that the runners-up came back to take the second, 6 to 0.

BERLIN, Sept. 26--All efforts to convince the Polish commander in Warsaw of the "horror and futility of resistance" having failed, the German High Command declared in a communique today that "action against Warsaw began yesterday."

The National Republican Club went on record last night in support of President Roosevelt's stand for revision of the Neutrality Act to permit the export of arms and munitions on a cash-and-carry basis.

The preservation of the traditional American liberties provided the keynote for speakers yesterday at the fortieth biennial session of the Patriotic Order, Sons of America, which is holding a three-day meeting at the Hotel Roosevelt.
BERLIN, Sept. 26 (AP)--Chancellor Hitler returned to Berlin tonight to concentrate his energies on the war on the Western Front.
An investing group represented by Kindale Estates, Inc., has purchased the six-story elevator apartment house on a plot 100 by 100 feet at 415-17 West Twenty-fourth Street, it was anounced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26-- Clerks in the House and Senate postoffices sighed with relief today as the flood of letters and postcards on neutrality legislation subsided.

The "house of genius" at 61 Washington Square South, where Theodore Dreiser, Eugene O'Neill, Alan Seeger, Frank Norris and many other writers have lived and worked, will be vacant and for rent Sunday.

PARIS, Sept. 26--Taking a step that had been regarded by many as inevitable ever since the GermanSoviet agreement was signed and especially since the Russian invasion of Poland, the French Government today issued a decree dissolving the Communist party in France.

NOWOGROD, Poland, Sept. 26-- The victorious German Army, which early this month broke through the supposedly impregnable Polish Narew fortifications within forty-eight hours, today evacuated all the territory east of the Pisia and Narew Rivers, which form the German-Russian demarcation...

Thaddeus Merriman of 380 Riverside Drive, consulting engineer and formerly chief engineer of the city's Board of Water Supply, with which he had been associated since 1905, died yesterday morning in the Park East Hospital, 112 East Eightythird Street, after a brief illness.

PARIS, Sept. 26--The terms of the proposed American neutrality amendment are commented on with favor here as representing an advantage for those powers able to buy and transport materials as well as for keeping the United States out of war.

With Columbia's first-string eleven now clicking sharply on the offense, Coach Lou Little has turned his attention to tightening the defense. Using the reserves for the attack, Little sent the regulars through a long defensive session at Baker Field yesterday, working the backs and linemen separately.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Sept. 26--Sweden flatly refuses to accept the German contraband declaration issued in Deutscher Dienst, official German news agency.

Steamship operators notified negotiators for the National Maritime Union, during a conference yesterday on a new wage and working agreement, that they were opposed strongly to the rotary' system of hiring, which is one of the demands
Price advances at wholesale of $1 to $2.50 per suit on Spring lines of boys', juniors' and students' clothing were indicated in the trade here yesterday.

While the number of New York City families changing their residence on Oct. 1 was estimated as 10 per cent fewer than in 1938, moving van owners forecast yesterday that 6,000 families would join the "moving day" rush over the weekend.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 26-- Dr. James B. Conant, president of Harvard University, told students at the first chapel services of the college year today that they were taking up their academic tasks in an atmosphere of uncertainty and tensity created by war, but expressed the belief that the world was not facing the end of civilization.
AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Sept. 26 (AP)--An unidentified seaplane, attaching from the rear, killed a passenger aboard a Netherland K.L.M. airliner off the German fortified island of Helgoland

Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick announced last night that the plan of the city to purchase certain types of Interborough Rapid Transit Company and Manhattan Railway Corporation securities for cash in the interest of hastening transit unification had been a "success."

The members of this year's Carnegie International jury of award left for Pittsburgh last night, where they will begin today their task of selecting the 1939 prize winners. As usual the jury consists of two European and two American artists.

TRENTON, Sept. 26--In the keynote speech at the opening session of the Democratic State Convention in the Stacy-Trent Hotel here today United States Senator William H. Smathers declared President Roosevelt could win "hands down" next year if he sought a third term

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 26-- Tony Mott, Yale halfback two seasons ago, today was assigned to the fullback position. He joined the squad yesterday, was promoted to the varsity this noon and three hours later took part in the Elis' second scrimmage of the campaign.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28--Representative Dies of Texas, chairman of the Committee on Un-American Activities, said today that the Roosevelt Administration had asked the Justice Department to begin "purging" about 2,850 "known Communists" who hold key government positions.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 26 (AP)--The metal trades department of the American Federation of Labor termed the Neutrality Arms Embargo Act unfair to "democratic nations" and asked Congress to revise the measure to permit free sale of American goods to all nations, in a report adopted today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 36.--Dr. Cyril Wynne, Chief of the Division of Research and Publication of the Department of State, died of a pistol wound early today. According to an office assistant who was in his house at the time arranging for him to go to a hospital, the wound was self-inflicted.
New fashions in corsets designed to induce the svelte lines required by the Fall silhouette were modeled at a showing at R.H. Macy Co. yesterday to a group of 250 women.
The Baltimore Ohio Railroad, an advocate of lower passenger fares, reported passenger revenues of $1,063,878 in August, against $890,314 in August, 1938.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Wednesday, Sept. 27 (AP)--John Sanford, 88, millionaire Amsterdam (N.Y.) carpet manufacturer and race horse owner, died last night in his hotel suite here.

Dr. Marvin A. (Mal) Stevens of N.Y.U., speaking at the luncheon of the Football Writers Association at Dempsey's Restaurant yesterday, predicted a wide open game when his Violet eleven meets Colgate at Hamilton, N.Y., Saturday.
BAHIA, Brazil, Sept. 26 (AP)-- Thirty-two survivors from the British freighter Royal Sceptre, sunk Sept. 7, arrived today aboard the British freighter Browning.

The sixteen-story apartment house on a plot 50 by 100 feet at 5-7 Van Houten Avenue, Jersey City, N.J., has been sold by the Prudentiel Insurance Company to the Van Houten Holding Corporation for a consideration shown as $57,000.
Russia's growing role in Europe was evidenced last night by an announcement that German Foreign Minister von Ribbentrop would pay a second visit to Moscow today.
BERLIN, Sept. 26--Chancellor Hitler returned from Poland late this afternoon on a special train that mounted anti-aircraft guns fore and aft.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 26--According to the news from Yeracruz, it appears now definitely established that the Columbus and the Arauca, two of the three German ships in port there, have been loading small quantities of Mexican oil.

Bent on knocking each other around lustily to the last, the Giants and Dodgers closed their personal account for the year at the Polo Grounds yesterday by splitting a double-header before a gathering of 13,499.

Exclusion of armed merchant ships from American ports during the war was advocated inferentially by John Bassett Moore, noted authority on international law, in a letter published yesterday in The New York Sun.

CAMDEN, N.J., Oct. 8--Access to the pulpits to which they had been assigned in Camden, Westville, Moorestown and Manasquan was denied today to pastors named by the New Jersey Methodist Conference, representing the Unified Methodist Episcopal and Methodist Protestant Churches.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8--The first of three delegations of Latin-American women who will make "goodwill" tours of the United States under the auspices of the Peoples Mandate to End War Committee arrived here today from New York.

In the presence of a congregation of 3,500 Bishop Stephen J. Donahue sang pontifical mass yesterday in St. Patrick's Cathedral, the ceremony marking the twenty-ninth anniversary of the consecration of the church.

Michael J. Quill, American Labor party Councilman, refused yesterday in a formal statement to subscribe to the anti-Communist resolution adopted a few days ago by the city-wide organization of the party. He charged that the resolution was actually "designed to create war hysteria."
CHICAGO, Oct. 8--Demand for cash lard has fallen off and many distributors who were large buyers in September are said to be trying now to dispose of lard purchased at much higher figures.

CHICAGO, Oct. 8--A sharp advance in waste-paper prices and correspondingly higher quotations on finished products have created such a scramble for box and other materials that many observers fear a collapse such as took place in the post-war commodity panic.

Charging that four of the organizations associated with the American Civil Liberties Union in the calling of a national conference on civil liberties next Friday and Saturday at the Hotel Biltmore are "Communist fronts," Louis Waldman ...

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8--Cut off from many of her foreign oil sources by the war and the increasing need for fuel for her military machine, Germany faces uncertain prospects of getting much help from the oil resources of Soviet Russia, the Commerce Department indicated today in a study of the Reich's foreign sources of crude and refined petroleum.

WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 8--Far down on the list at the conclusion of the first eighteen holes of play yesterday, the Piping Rock combination of Jimmy Curtis and Kenneth Bourne put together a pair of brilliant 61s today to capture the, Meadow Brook Club's annual Fall invitation handicap golf tournament.
OTTAWA, Oct. 8 (Canadian Press)--Ultimate victory for the Allies in the war and revolution in Germany and Russia were predicted here by Victor Podoski, Polish consul general to Canada.

ROME, Oct. 8.--The Italian market, which at the beginning of last week showed a tendency to rise, had some fluctuations subsequently. Its rise was followed by a alight fall in almost all industrial shares. The ...

The one-story industrial building on a plot 81 by 120 feet at 128-32 Mount Pleasant Avenue, in Newark, N. J., has been sold by the True Friends Building and Loan Association to the Newark Felt Base Company, which will add another floor to the structure and use it as a warehouse for itself and a subsidiary, the Katz Linoleum Company. Leo Flaster was the broker.
CHARLOTTE, N.C., Oct. 8-- "With the war cutting off practically all exportations of dyestuffs from Europe, the world is turning to the United States for its dye, with the result that we are being ...
Three Roman Catholic Archbishops joined in a coast-to-coast broadcast yesterday to urge support of mission activities and the observance among Catholics of Mission Sunday on Oct. 22.

The 5,000 stars nearest to the earth, many of which are visible to the naked eye, are only a half to a third as far off as the average distance calculated by astronomers, according to Professor Jan Schilt, head of the Rutherfurd Observatory, Columbia University.
LONDON, Oct. 8--While heading into Weymouth, England, for contraband examination, the Netherland freighter Binnendijk was sunk off Shambles Lighthouse in the darkness early this morning.

Under the influence of hedging of the new crop and peace talk in Europe, cotton prices worked lower last week on the local market. The decline was gradual and orderly, however, in consequence of trade buying against recent large sales of goods. On the New York Cotton Exchange active old-type contracts closed 11 to 20 points lower than the week ended on Sept. 30.

The Swedish Hospital in Brooklyn dedicated a new building with 100 beds on Dean Street near Bedford Avenue yesterday afternoon. Count Folke Bernadotte, Swedish Commissioner to the World's Fair; Consul General Martin Kastengren, Supreme Court Justice William F. Hagarty and former Justice Peter B. Hanson of the Domestic Relations Court, president of the hospital, participated.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP)--The Supreme Court is expected to announce tomorrow whether it will review seven controversies involving interpretation of the National Labor Relations Act.

Samuel E. Hoyt of New Haven, Conn., national president of the Amateur Athletic Union, was critically injured at 10 o'clock yesterday morning, and his wife, Mrs. Grace Hoyt, was hurt when the automobile in which they were riding was in collision with another at Parsons Boulevard and Twentieth Avenue, Whitestone, Queens.
CHICAGO, Oct. 8--A revival in the European demand for American cash corn had relatively little effect on the market last week, although it is estimated that 2,000,000 bushels were sold to go abroad.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 8--Paul Derringer's collapse in the fourth game of the world series today was all the more remarkable because of the smoothness and economy of motion he showed early in the contest. He made only twenty-nine pitches in the first four innings.

Wholesale market activity continued at a god pace last week, with heavy orders arriving on better dresses, sportswear, holiday accessory items for men and women, gift merchandise of all types and piece goods. Interest in dinner and ...

Despite overcast skies and the complete absence of crowd-drawing events on the day's program, the World's Fair attracted again yesterday a huge throng that took its place as the third largest since the Fair opened and sent the total paid attendance for the season to within 68,136 of the 22,000,000 mark.
CLEVELAND, Oct. 8 (AP)--The massive Chicago Bears battered down the Cleveland Rams, 35 to 21, today in a National League football game played in 87-degree heat before 18,209 fans.

George Z. Medalie, president of the New York County Lawyers Association, will head the 1939 joint campaign for funds of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies of New York City and the Brooklyn Federation of Jewish Charities, it was announced yesterday.

Mayor La Guardia accepted yesterday the resignation of Alfred Rheinstein as chairman of the New York City Housing Authority and director of Public Housing. Mr. Rheinstein tendered his resignation last Tuesday, effective at "the earliest possible moment."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 8--Reports that Metro is planning to film a life of Benjamin Franklin with Spencer Tracy have caused Warners to revive a similar project announced two years ago and to assign Edward G. Robinson to the historical story, the latter studio disclosed.

EAST ISLIP, L.I., Oct. 8--Wingan's Daily Double, Labrador dog owned and handled by Howes Burton of Babylon, L.I., advanced one step today along the road to retriever field trial recognition by winning the novice stake held under the auspices of the Long Island Retriever Field Trial Club on the Hollins Estate.

BERLIN, Oct. 8--German industry and trade are availing themselves of a short lull between the termination of the "lightning" war in the East and the start of actual fighting in the West for readjust ment to war conditions.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Oct. 8-- Australian opinion on Chancellor Hitler's speech was reflected by Prime Minister Robert Gordon Menzies' observation that it was not a peace offer, but a blustery attempt to justify war.
PARIS, Oct. 8.--Lucien Lelong, president of the "Chambre Syndicale de la Couture Parisienne," has made his first official statement to the press as to the wartime organization of Paris couture.

The official measure of industrial activity in the United States is the Federal Reserve Board's index of industrial production. The announcement that the adjusted index has moved from 102 per cent of the 1923-25 average in August to 110 in September summarizes better than any other single statement could the present level of business activity and the extent of recovery.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8--The Navy Department announced today that the American steamship, the Iroquois, which German Grand Admiral Erich Raeder said was to be sunk as it neared the American coast, had been met by the flotilla of destroyers and a Coast Guard boat which will accompany the ship to New York under orders of President Roosevelt.

Reporting for the first time on a survey it made in March, 1938, of New Jersey commuter traffic, the Port of New York Authority announced yesterday that 318,000 persons travel daily to Manhattan by all facilites, including automobiles. Railroad passengers make up 130,000 of the total.

CHICAGO, Oct. 8 (AP)--The White Sox spotted the Cubs five runs and then defeated the National League leaders today, 8 to 5, in ten innings to prolong their city championship series for at least one more game. The Cubs now have won three games and the White Sox two.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 8-- Miss Jean Gedney was married here this afternoon to John Howard Burbank, son of Mrs. David R. Burbank of Ridgewood and the late Mr. Burbank, in the home of her aunt, Mrs. John Leslie Crosthwaite, with whom she has lived for many years. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Lloyd Foster of Calvary Methodist Episcopal Church.

A protest against any provisions in the proposed trade agreement with Belgium which would reduce the present rates of duty on carpets, mats or rugs made wholly or chiefly of jute has been made in a statement sent by the Institute of Carpet Manufacturers of America, Inc., to Oscar Ryder, chairman of the ...
Superior artillery won the world series. But the Yankees not only laid down the heavier curtain of fire: they held control of the air from the start.

The forensic activity that has characterized Union Square for decades was suspended yesterday afternoon as the regular habitues of that locality turned from political and economic harangues to watch the city-wide championships in paddle tennis and shuffleboard sponsored by the Police Athletic League.

Miss Mary W. Pander Poel is chairman of a junior committee for a White Elephant cocktail party and tea dance to be given tomorrow in the St. Regis Roof under the auspices of the Thrift Shop committee of the State Charities Aid Association. Patrons of the party are asked to bring used articles suitable for resale.
Brooklyn College defeated Fort Hamilton, 20-8, for its first football victory in three starts yesterday at the army reservation in Brooklyn before 2,000.

Tonight means no more than any other to Main Street. The lights of that thoroughfare have so thoroughly assumed ascendancy over the heavens that even the moon seems more pallid than poets paint her.
William H. Yates has been appointed controller of United Wall Paper Factories, Inc. He was formerly controller for Lady Esther, Ltd.

JERUSALEM, Oct. 8.--A memorial to an American Jew will be started in Palestine next Tuesday when foundations will be laid for seventy farms at Kfar Felix Warburg, meaning Felix Warburg village, in southern Palestine near the Jewish colony of Beertuvia.

Despite the intimation from London last week that a quota restriction system of some sort might be set up by the Distillers Corporation, Ltd., importers of Scotch whisky will go ahead with plans for advertising in newspapers and magazines, they have reported. Despite ...

Warning America that one of the greatest perils facing it today is "our failure to see our need of repentance," the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell urged that we should not stand aloof and thank God that we are not like other foolish nations leaping at each other's throats.

CHICAGO, Oct. 8--Grain traders still are hoping that the European war will get the wheat market out of the rut into which it apparently has fallen following a few days of hectic trading after the outbreak of hostilities abroad.

PARIS, Oct. 8--It is no task to be a member of the Polish Government in today's circumstances, August Zaleski, new Polish Foreign Minister said here today in reply to questions about the plans and prospects of the Polish Government set up in France.

LONDON, Oct. 8 (UP)--Informed quarters predicted today that when Great Britain replies to Chancellor Hitler's peace offer it would include the requisite that Germany must withdraw from all territories forcibly occupied before any conference can be considered.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Oct. 8-- Apparently determined to make no move toward ending European hostilities until assured in advance of the support for his purpose of all the belligerent powers, President Roosevelt refused today to break his silence on officially prompted Berlin suggestions that he offer to mediate.

"Columbus," a one-act opera by Eugene Zador, with text by the Archduke Joseph Franz of Hungary, received its world premiere, under Erno Rapee's direction, yesterday noon at the Center Theatre. The novelty was presented as a feature of the "Radio City Music Hall on the Air" series and was broadcast over WJZ and the NBC Blue Network.

Father Coughlin and the organizations making up the Christian Front were denounced as un-American and un-Christian in spirit by the Rev. Dr. Howard D. McGrath, pastor of the Grace Methodist Church, 131 West 104th Street, in his sermon yesterday morning.

BERLIN, Oct. 8--Nazi leaders contemptuously dismissed tonight the first negative replies to Adolf Hitler's peace proposals with the allegation that the London and Paris Governments were misrepresenting the "real desires for peace" among the British and French people.

The United States can stay out of war if it has an understanding of what war is, the desire to avoid it and the will to serve humanity and not belligerent nations, John Hayes Holmes, pastor of the Community Church, declared yesterday in his sermon at Town Hall, 123 West Forty-third Street.
Sinclair Lewis has delivered to Doubleday, Doran the typescript of his new novel, "Bethel Merriday," the story of a young girl in the theatre. Publication will be in March.

The discontinuance of the Bachelor of Science in Social Science degree, which City College granted to more than 1,300 graduates last year, is recommended in a report to the college's faculty by its Curriculum Committee, according to an announcement yesterday by Dean Morton Gottschall, chairman.
The hunting and salt-water fishing prospects for this month seem to be improving every day as reports come from the States from Maine to New Jersey.
LONDON, Oct. 8--King George VI returned to London today after a visit to the Home Fleet at its secret war station in the North that lasted two days.

The American Importer and the American Banker of the United States Line sailed yesterday on their third trips to pick up Americans stranded in Europe.
The remodeling of Washington Square Park by the Department of Parks and the WPA will probably get under way about Nov. 1, according to indications yesterday.

The annual registration and enrollment of voters begins today and will continue throughout the week. Places of registration in each election district in the city will be open today through Friday from 5 P.M. to 10:30 P.M. On Saturday, the final day, the hours will be from 7 A.M. to 10:30 P.M.
LONDON, Oct. 8--A German flyingboat was shot down in a fight over the North Sea today by a number of reconnoissance aircraft of the Royal Air Force out on patrol duty.

Dr. Dennis J. McDonald, retired ear, nose and throat specialist, died yesterday in an Astoria, Queens, sanitarium after an illness of five years. He was 74 years old.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 8-- Our Way, bay gelding owned by Mrs. Harry Frank Jr. of Warrenville, won the working hunter championship as the three-day program of the nineteenth annual Orange Horse Show ended at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club today.

Elsewhere on this page we publish a letter from the executive secretary of the American Association for Social Security based on reports published in a number of Ohio newspapers that Administrator McNutt favors the reimbursement to Ohio of the $1,338,160 withheld about a year ago by the Social Security Board on the ground that the State's old-age assistance system was being improperly administered.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 8--Marse Joe McCarthy's mighty Yankees, beyond question the most amazing club in the 100-year history of baseball, inscribed another brilliant page upon the records of the game today when they crushed the Cincinnati Reds in ten innings, 7 to 4, to close the 1939 world series in a whirl of statistics that attested still further to their greatness.

Mr. and Mrs. Blakeman Quintard Meyer of Rye, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mae-Beaven Meyer, to Hamilton Jerome Whitlock, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Allen Whitlock of 1,185 Park Avenue, this city.
WASHINGTON Oct. 8--The second week of debate on the Neutrality Bill will open in the Senate tomorrow with every prospect of victory (possibly a quick one) for the Administration.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 8 (AP)--The $5,614.26 each of the series pool that the Yankees earned today as the individual shares of the world series winners fell only $168.50 short of equaling the all-time high in a four-game series.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8--Despite the Herculean efforts of Ace Parker, always a one-man gang, win, lose, or draw, the Brooklyn Football Dodgers suffered one of the worst defeats in their history today before 27,092 sweltering fans at Griffith Stadium, home of the Redskins.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Oct. 8 (AP)--William Morton of Watsonville, Calif., who served as United States vice consul in Warsaw, reached Bucharest today after being detained by the Soviet army almost three weeks.

ROME, Oct. 8--Should Britain and France reject Chancellor Hitler's peace proposals, Italy will continue with renewed vigor her efforts to build and maintain a "neutral bloc," according to circles close to the government.
It has been our habit for years to seek out by day and after dark those places in town that seem to fit the hour's mood.

A plot 100 by 194 feet on the east side of Brighton Thirteenth Street, in Brighton Beach, Brooklyn, has been sold by Joseph P. Day to Jacob Somers, builder, who plans to erect a three-story apartment building there.

PARIS, Oct. 8--The police in Paris and agents of the National Surety service in the provinces today began a round-up of former Communist Deputies and late tonight announced the arrest of thirty-five of them. Almost all of the former party's chief leaders, however, have evaded capture and are believed to be in hiding somewhere within the country.

A jungle picture from Guatemala, if used for illustrative photography, is not necessarily made in Guatemala, and two gentlemen raising their whisky glasses before the picturesque background of a Mexican patio may never have seen the original beauty of Spanish architecture.

Seven are named for today's opening-day feature at Jamaica, which will stage the eighth of the nine race meetings of the Jockey Club season. On the strength of his excellent winning race on Saturday, it is possible that William Goetz's Woodberry will go to the post the favorite in the six-furlong Belgrade Claiming Stakes, which carries with it $2,500 in added money.

MOSCOW, Oct. 8--Germany and Russia have agreed to realize their program of economic collaboration 'at a rapid pace and on a large scale," a Soviet communique said tonight.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Oct, 8Without losing a single race, the Larchmont Yacht Club's Class B team today successfully defended the Dinghy Challenge Cup which the Royal Bermuda Yacht Club put up five years ago.

BERLIN, Oct. 8 (AP)--Dogs capable of being trained as field messengers will be "drafted" into the German Army. Owners of such breeds as shepherds, Airedales, terriers and boxers were ordered to report them, starting tomorrow.
PITTSBURGH, Oct.8--Output of steel ingots in the United States last week continued its upward trend and reached 87 per cent of capacity, up 3 points from the previous week.

The fantastic story of a former inmate of the Central Islip State Hospital, Central Islip, L.I., who for nearly three years lived in a tent in a thickly wooded section in the center of Staten Island, was unfolded last night by police after the arrest of Frederick Nolte, 34 years old, on a charge of burglary and possession of burglar tools.

LONDON, Oct. 8--The difficulty of reconciling the interests involved in the British desire to respect Belgium's vital trading interests and the determination to enforce a strict blockade of Germany is engaging the attention of the two governments.

Cecil Dashwood Giles, head of the firm of certified public accountants of his name at 67 Wall Street, died Saturday night of a heart attack at his residence, 600 West 218th Street, in his sixty-fifth year.

Dr. George Washington Carver, noted Negro agricultural chemist, Major Gen. Frank R. McCoy, U.S.A. retired, and Carl Sandburg, poet and author, are the recipients of the Roosevelt Medals for 1939, it was announced yesterday by James R. Garfield, president of the Roosevelt Memorial Association.

CHICAGO, Oct. 8--In its second year of operation the payroll tax climbed to third place among all taxes, according to an analysis of 1938 tax receipts of Federal, State and local governments released by the Federation of Tax Administrators.

TOKYO, Monday, Oct. 9--Efforts to settle the Foreign Office dispute over the plan to transfer the economic section to the Trade Ministry failed at 2 o'clock this morning when Foreign Minister Kichisaburo Nomura rejected a compromise plan prepared by the 150 striking employes of the section.
NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 8--Holy Name Society parades were held this afternoon in many communities in the Archdiocese of Newark and the Diocese of Paterson, with 150,000 participating.

PARIS, Oct. 8--Possibly as initial preparation for their eventual large-scale offensive, German scouting parties were numerous in no man's land today, especially east of the Moselle. This is the sector where many persons believe that the strongest thrust may occur.

Gates, dean of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, said yesterday in his sermon at the cathedral, Amsterdam Avenue and 112th Street.

ALBANY, Oct. 9--A letter of acceptance of a post as a director of the Foreign Petroleum Corporation written by County Judge George W. Martin in 1927 figured largely in the testimony before the State Senate tonight in the Martin removal proceedings. The session was the first to be held at night.

TRENTON, N.J., Tuesday, Oct. 10--By a bare majority vote, 31--28, the Republican-controlled State Assembly early today passed a bill creating a five-member non-salaried commission to regulate parimueuel betting on horse races.

LONDON, Oct. 9.--The feature of the stock markets today was the further modest expansion in the gilt-edge section. Prices were firm and with only a few exceptions it was fairly easy to sell at or slightly above the minimum prices. Other groups were generally quiet with a solid undertone.

George Biddle's first one-man show in two years opened with a reception yesterday afternoon at the Associated American Artists' Galleries, 711 Fifth Avenue. It opens to the public today and will continue until Oct. 23.
Russia's march around the rim of the Baltic Sea ran into an obstacle yesterday in the form of a Finland determined, according to her press, to maintain her neutrality and hence her independence.
LONDON, Oct. 9--As fast as they can be loaded aboard ships and transported across the Channel British troops are being poured into France.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9--Laura Ingalls asserted today before the Civil Aeronautics Authority that she was aware of a government regulation against dropping objects from an aeroplane but that she had never considered a leaflet to be an "object."

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Oct. 9--Mme. Ganna Walska, the singer, was among the passengers arriving here today from Lisbon on the American Clipper. Returning after three years abroad, she said she way glad to be back and that it seemed like an eternity since she was here last.

Miss Lena Phillips, 28-year-old domestic employed in the household of Dr. Alfred Lachs, a chemist, at 1,046 Teller Avenue, the Bronx, was shot and killed yesterday when she returned from a morning errand with some breakfast rolls and a newspaper for her employer.
The George Washington Bridge, considered one of the most graceful suspension bridges in the world and the second most popular Hudson crossing, was eight years old yesterday.

After a lapse of almost eight years the Japanese yen has abandoned sterling and gone back to the dollar. The step was announced yesterday but actually was taken on Oct. 2. Not since then has there been any variation in the yen-dollar price.

Out of an experience of twenty years as head of three universities in three sections of the United States (South, West and East), Chancellor Chase makes an authoritative and interesting survey of the field of higher education in America during the two decades since the World War.

ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 24 (AP)--Assurance that New York City would receive "plenty of milk" in the event of action by the up-State New York Dairy Farmers Union against producers who fail to pay $2.15 a hundred weight for September milk same today from union officials.

CHICAGO, Oct. 24--Joe DiMaggio, whose big bat earned him the batting championship and helped propel the Yankees to a fourth straight world title, today was named the most valuable player in the American League for the 1939 season.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 24--Herbert Hoover, writing in this week's issue of The Saturday Evening Post, says the "voice of experience" warns that, whether or not we take part in the present European war, "we face a further quarter of a century of difficulty " and if we do partcipate "we can expect another quarter of a century of impoverishment."
Margaretta, Countess of Winchilsea has returned from London, and is at Mayfair House. Mr. and Mrs. John B. Clark have come from Newport to the Ambassador.

LONDON, Oct. 24--The Archbishop of York said last night that if Britain is in a position at the end of the war to influence a new settlement she must be prepared to choose batween national sovereignty and collective security.
BERLIN, Oct. 24--Germany's future soldiers, Hitler Youth members from 16 to 18 years old, are calied up for six months' semi-military training, it was announced today.

The Queen Mary and the Normandie, largest, fastest and most luxurious liners of the British and French merchant marine fleet, were put under heavier guard last night after reports reached the police that one would be sabotaged within the next few days.

With fourteen new cases of diphtheria reported in the city during the week ended last Saturday, more immunizations of young children were urged by Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner, yesterday. The college basketball season at Madison Square Garden will start on Dec. 16 and will present the heaviest schedule arranged by the midtown arena since the introduction of the sport there. The number of American voters who believe the United States will be drawn into the European war has decreased sharply since hostilities started, according to a survey made public yesterday by the American Institute of Public Opinion, of which Dr. George Gallup is director.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 24--With President Harold W. Dodds and Dean Christian Gauss watching from the University Field stands, Princeton's freshman football players put up a stiff fight against the varsity in a scrimmage today, scoring the first touchdown they have been able to register against the regulars this season.

BERLIN, Oct. 24 (U.P.)--Crowds stormed Berlin's candy stores today when word got around that authorities were permitting stores that still had supplies of chocolate to sell it in boxes costing not less than two marks as long as existing stocks lasted. Most candy stores were sold out by evening. No further supplies of chocolate will be available, it was said.

YONKERS, N.Y., Oct. 24--Surrounded by colorful Autumnal foliage, 3,500,000 chrysanthemum blooms of every size and shape were displayed here today when Samuel Untermyer opened his estate, Greystone, to the public. With visiting hours from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M., the exhibition will continue a week.

Directors of the Barber Asphalt Company declared yesterday a dividend of 25 cents a share on the common stock. This is the first dividend on that stock since Nov, 16, 1937, when 75 cents a share was distributed.

AMHERST, Mass., Oct. 24--Coach Lloyd Jordan, who has been producing formidable football teams at Amherst for the last eight years, has another potentially fine eleven this season. DENVER, Oct. 30 (AP)--The world welterweight champion, Henry Armstrong, scored a technical knockout over Bobby Pacho of Los Angeles in the fourth round of their scheduled fifteen-round title bout before 4,500 at Municipal Auditorium tonight. Armstrong weighed 140 pounds, Pacho 146.

A Federal grand jury investigation into new and serious charges involving the German-American Bund was disclosed yesterday when James Wheeler-Hill, national secretary of the Bund, appeared at the Federal Court House in response to a grand jury subpoena.

Directors of the Standard Oil Company of Indiana yesterday declared an extra dividend of 25 cents a share on the capital stock, in addition to the regular quarterly payment of that amount. This will lift total payments by the company this year to $1.25 a share, against $1 in 1938.
